name: sun
test: Start early in the morning when the sun is approaching the garden area. Every hour draw a rough line where the sun is shining or shadows are cast with a note as to the time. Repeat this every hour until the sun is past the area.

results.description: Less than 3 hours of sun per day.
results.details: In environments with less light, plants grow more slowly and use less water. Avoid overwatering by feeling the soil.

results.description: 3-6 hours of sun per day or 4-6 hours of inconsistent sun per day.
results.details: These plants will not dry out as quickly; avoid overwatering by feeling the soil.
High-light areas can be warm, making plants dry out faster. Check these plants more frequently and water when soil is dry.

name: soil
test: Take half a cup of your soil, add a little water and mix until there are no lumps, drain excess moisture and form the soil into a ball in the palm of your hand.

results.description: Easily falls apart and contains gritty grains when rubbed.
results.details: Sandy soil does not hold nutrients well but drains well.

results.description: Soil holds its shape but will easily break apart.
results.details: Soil with roughly equal proportions of sand, silt, and clay.

results.description: Soil will hold its shape: it is hard sticky and elastic, fine and smooth textured.
results.details: Clay excludes air and can become easily waterlogged but is extremely fertile as it holds nutrients well.

name: moisture
test: Get a handful of soil, squeeze into a ball and attempt to poke a finger in it.

results.description: Doesn't form a ball or falls apart.
results.details: Dry soil will need about 1 inch of water per week.

results.description: Soil sticks together but falls apart when touched.
results.details: Water regulates soil temperature and promotes healthy soil.

results.description: Continues to hold together and even molds to the shape.
results.details: Working your soil when it's too wet or dry also damages the structure of the soil.

name: ph
test: Place 2 tablespoons of soil in a bowl and moisten it with distilled water. Place another 2 tablespoons of soil in a bowl and add ½ cup vinegar. Add ½ cup baking soda to each.

results.description: If the baking soda mixture fizzes, you have acidic soil.
results.details: Acidic (“sour”) soil is counteracted by applying finely ground limestone or wood ash.
